> From: Andy Kriger 
> 
> Good point. In this case, however, there is a wealth of test 
> files (the
> backup PDBs from my Visor) which I can use to validate the 
> object model.

The problem I see with that is: read/compare but compare to what ?

> 
> But the idea is still the same - read/write/compare or 
> write/read/compare.
> Are these the only tests you do for this kind of behavior?
>

Basicaly, yes.
The idea being that my model has classes that encapsulate translation to and
from XML (chain-of-responsibility with specific handlers for different type
of objects). I don't want to make my tests dependent on the actual XML
format (or any other format) being used. Which makes me free to change the
format at any time, and still have valid tests.
I do this both at the translation level and a higher level where actual
serialization takes place.
At the translation level handlers have:
	public org.w3c.dom.Document write(Object object)
	public Object read(org.w3c.dom.Document)
in the test:
	MyObject object = new MyObjectImpl();
	document = handler.write(object);
	assertNotNull(document);
	MyObject objectReadBack = (MyObject)handler.read(document);
	...

The only thing to verify is that the tests cover the entire state of the
original instance and the instance read back.
It is possible to make a helper class that uses reflection to discover all
getXxx(...), isYyy(...), hasZzz(...) and compare two instances (maybe
somebody has done that already ?). Then use that in the tests to assert
equality.
